Data.event_text: 3 January  19 people are killed and homes and other buildings are burned by unidentified gunmen in Tawari, Kogi State.

links.text: -"Unidentified gunmen kill 19 people in central Nigeria". www.aljazeera.com. Retrieved 7 September 2020.-

Data.event_text: 6 January  2020 Gamboru bombing 30 killed and 35 injured in a bomb explosion in Gamboru, Borno State, apparently by Boko Haram.

links.text: -Nigeria hit by deadly bomb attack near Cameroon Archived 3 February 2020 at the Wayback Machine Deutsche Welle, 7 January 2020-
-Nigeria hit by deadly bomb attack near Cameroon Archived 3 February 2020 at the Wayback Machine Deutsche Welle, 7 January 2020-

Data.event_text: 8 January  American rapper Cardi B announces she will seek Nigerian citizenship.

links.text: -"Cardi B's pledge to seek Nigerian citizenship sparks rivalry". AP NEWS. 8 January 2020. Retrieved 7 September 2020.-

Data.event_text: 15 January  50th anniversary of the end of the Nigerian Civil War (1967-1970).

links.text: -Nigerians mark 50 years of the end of bloody civil war Archived 4 February 2020 at the Wayback Machine by Fidelis Mbah, Al Jazeera, 15 January 2020-
-Nigerians mark 50 years of the end of bloody civil war Archived 4 February 2020 at the Wayback Machine by Fidelis Mbah, Al Jazeera, 15 January 2020-

Data.event_text: 16 January  Three aid workers who were held hostage since 22 December 2019 are released in Borno State.

links.text: -Armed group frees kidnapped hostages in Nigeria Archived 4 February 2020 at the Wayback Machine Al Jazeera, 16 January 2020-
-Armed group frees kidnapped hostages in Nigeria Archived 4 February 2020 at the Wayback Machine Al Jazeera, 16 January 2020-

Data.event_text: 24 January  Lassa fever outbreak kills 29 in 11 states this month.

links.text: -Lassa fever outbreak kills dozens in Nigeria Archived 4 February 2020 at the Wayback Machine Al Jazeera, 31 January 2020-
-Lassa fever outbreak kills dozens in Nigeria Archived 4 February 2020 at the Wayback Machine Al Jazeera, 31 January 2020-

Data.event_text: 31 January  U.S. President Donald Trump expands the travel ban to include Nigeria and five other countries.

links.text: -Trump expands travel ban to six additional countries Archived 4 February 2020 at the Wayback Machine Al Jazeera, 27 January 2020-
-Trump expands travel ban to six additional countries Archived 4 February 2020 at the Wayback Machine Al Jazeera, 27 January 2020-

Data.event_text: 1 February  A ban on commercial motorcycles goes into effect in Lagos State.

links.text: -Nigeria: Effects of Okada, Keke Ban Bite Harder As Lagosians Resume Work Archived 5 February 2020 at the Wayback Machine By Taofeekat Ajayi, Premium Times (allAfrica), 4 February 2020, retrieved 8 February 2020-

-Nigeria: Effects of Okada, Keke Ban Bite Harder As Lagosians Resume Work Archived 5 February 2020 at the Wayback Machine By Taofeekat Ajayi, Premium Times (allAfrica), 4 February 2020, retrieved 8 February 2020-

Data.event_text: US $300 million (£230 million) seized from former president Sani Abacha's laundered accounts will be returned to Nigeria.

links.text: -"Jersey bank's £230m seizure set to be returned to Nigeria". BBC News. 4 February 2020. Archived from the original on 4 February 2020.-
-"Jersey bank's £230m seizure set to be returned to Nigeria". BBC News. 4 February 2020. Archived from the original on 4 February 2020.-

Data.event_text: Senate approves budget for customs.

links.text: -2020 budget: Senate okays N238.15bn for Customs Archived 4 February 2020 at the Wayback Machine Daily Post, 4 February 2020-
-2020 budget: Senate okays N238.15bn for Customs Archived 4 February 2020 at the Wayback Machine Daily Post, 4 February 2020-

Data.event_text: 7 February  American rapper Lil Wayne says, "I'm more Nigerian than American."

links.text: -Nigeria: I'm More Nigerian Than American - Lil Wayne Archived 7 February 2020 at the Wayback Machine allAfrica, retrieved 7 February 2020-
-Nigeria: I'm More Nigerian Than American - Lil Wayne Archived 7 February 2020 at the Wayback Machine allAfrica, retrieved 7 February 2020-

Data.event_text: 9 February  At least 30 people killed in Auno, Borno State, apparently by Boko Haram.

links.text: -"Suspected Boko Haram Fighters Kill at Least 30 in Nigeria". The New York Times. Reuters. 10 February 2020. Archived from the original on 11 February 2020. At least 30 people have been killed in Nigeria's northeastern Borno region after suspected Boko Haram fighters set ablaze several trucks carrying passengers on Sunday night, eyewitnesses and residents told Reuters.-

-"Suspected Boko Haram Fighters Kill at Least 30 in Nigeria". The New York Times. Reuters. 10 February 2020. Archived from the original on 11 February 2020. At least 30 people have been killed in Nigeria's northeastern Borno region after suspected Boko Haram fighters set ablaze several trucks carrying passengers on Sunday night, eyewitnesses and residents told Reuters.-

Data.event_text: 14 February  International flights to Murtala Muhammed International Airport in Lagos are diverted to Kotoka International Airport in Accra, Ghana, due to poor weather and complications with new equipment.

links.text: -Aisha Salaudeen (14 February 2020). "International flights to Lagos divert to Ghana due to poor equipment, leaving passengers stranded". CNN World.-

Data.event_text: 27 February  A stolen bronze statue from Ifẹ in the Yoruba kingdom is seized at the Mexico City International Airport and returned to Nigeria. The statue is later found to be a fake.

links.text: -Mexico returns ancient bronze sculpture to Nigeria Archived 15 November 2022 at the Wayback Machine BBC, 27 February 2020-
-Mexico returns ancient bronze sculpture to Nigeria Archived 15 November 2022 at the Wayback Machine BBC, 27 February 2020-
-Yoruba archeological piece Mexico returned to Nigeria is false Archived 15 November 2022 at the Wayback Machine El Universal, 18 March 2020-
-Yoruba archeological piece Mexico returned to Nigeria is false Archived 15 November 2022 at the Wayback Machine El Universal, 18 March 2020-

Data.event_text: 28 February  The Federal Ministry of Health has confirmed an Italian citizen who works in Lagos has been confirmed as the first case of COVID-19 in Nigeria and sub-Saharan Africa.

links.text: -"Nigeria confirms first coronavirus case in Sub-Saharan Africa". France 24. 28 February 2020. Retrieved 28 February 2020.-

Data.event_text: 4 March - Four police officers and two militiamen were killed by Boko Haram militants during a raid on an army base in Damboa, Borno State.

links.text: -"Six killed in attack on Nigeria military base". www.aljazeera.com.-

Data.event_text: 9 March  The emir of Kano, Lamido Sanusi, is dethroned for "disrespect to lawful instructions".

links.text: -Influential Nigerian traditional ruler dethroned Archived 26 March 2020 at the Wayback Machine Al Jazeera, 9 March 2020-
-Influential Nigerian traditional ruler dethroned Archived 26 March 2020 at the Wayback Machine Al Jazeera, 9 March 2020-

Data.event_text: 15 March - Abule-Ado explosion, Lagos State, killed at least 15 people and destroyed around 50 buildings.

links.text: -Ukomadu, Angela; Sanni, Seun; Eboh, Camillus; Ohuocha, Chijioke (15 March 2020). Maclean, William; Hudson, Alexandra (eds.). "Lagos gas blast kills 15, destroys several buildings, Nigerian officials say". Reuters. An explosion at a gas processing plant on Sunday killed at least 15 people and destroyed about 50 buildings after a fire broke out in a suburb of Lagos, Nigeria's commercial capital, emergency services said. The Nigerian National Petroleum Corporation (NNPC) said the explosion was triggered after a truck hit some gas cylinders stacked in a gas processing plant near the corporation's pipeline in Abule Ado area of Lagos state.-

Data.event_text: 24 March   Chad and Nigeria massacres About 70 soldiers are ambushed and killed by Boko Haram in Goneri village, Borno State.

links.text: -At least 50 Nigerian soldiers killed in Boko Haram ambush Archived 26 March 2020 at the Wayback Machine Al Jazeera, 24 March 2020-
-At least 50 Nigerian soldiers killed in Boko Haram ambush Archived 26 March 2020 at the Wayback Machine Al Jazeera, 24 March 2020-

Data.event_text: 13 April  People of African origin, including Nigerians, have faced discrimination in Guangzhou and elsewhere in China. Africans from Nigeria, Togo and Benin have been evicted from hotels in the middle of the night, a group of African students was forced to take COVID-19 tests despite not having travelled recently, and others reported being threatened with having their visas and work permits revoked.

links.text: -Givetash, Linda; Moschella, Matteo (20 April 2020). "China accused of discriminating against Africans as part of coronavirus fight". NBC News. Retrieved 20 April 2020.-

Data.event_text: 17 April  Considerable fake news about the coronavirus is circulating in Africa.

links.text: -"Coronavirus: What misinformation has spread in Africa?". BBC News. Retrieved 20 April 2020.-

Data.event_text: 18 April   Katsina attacks Armed bandits kill 47 people in attacks on villages in Katsina State.

links.text: -Hazzad, Ardo (19 April 2020). "'Armed bandits' kill 47 in northwest Nigeria's Katsina state: police". Reuters. Retrieved 19 April 2020.-

Data.event_text: 19 April  Twenty-one employees of ExxonMobil from Akwa Ibom State were arrested for violating state quarantine standards in Rivers State, but were released when the union threatened industrial action. It is unknown if any of the arrested men have symptoms of infection.

links.text: -Owolabi, Tife (19 April 2020). "Nigerian oil union suspends industrial action after Exxon Mobil workers freed". Reuters. Retrieved 20 April 2020.-

Data.event_text: 23 April  Nigeria has tested only 7,153 people for COVID-19, 0.03% of the population. 873 cases and 28 deaths have been reported, but the Africa Centers for Disease Control fears the numbers may go much higher.

links.text: -Imray, Gerald (23 April 2020). "Africa's 43% jump in virus cases in 1 week worries experts". Associated Press. Retrieved 24 April 2020.-

Data.event_text: 25 April  The Central Bank of Nigeria took 1.47 trillion naira ($3.8 billion) from lenders as additional cash reserves for failing to meet regulatory targets.

links.text: -Osae-Brown, Anthony; Onu, Emele (25 April 2020). "Nigerian Banks to Take $3.8 Billion Hit for Missing Targets". Bloomberg News. Retrieved 26 April 2020.-

Data.event_text: 28 April  Gravediggers in Kano report a mysterious increase in deaths. There is speculation that the deaths may be linked to the coronavirus pandemic, but no one knows since autopsies are not routinely done. Another possibility is that the deaths may be related to other underlying diseases such as hypertension, diabetes, meningitis and acute malaria that have gone untreated because many hospitals are closed.

links.text: -Izundu, Chi Chi (28 April 2020). "What is behind Nigeria's unexplained deaths in Kano?". BBC News. Retrieved 28 April 2020.-

Data.event_text: 30 April  Confirmed COVID-19 cases in Kano triple from 77 at the beginning of the week to 219 as health authorities ramp up "verbal autopsies".  State officials insist most of the fatalities were due to other diseases rather than COVID-19. Nasiru Sani Gwarzo, head of the presidential COVID-19 taskforce sent to Kano, said the rise in deaths was also due to cuts to medical services for other ailments as a result of the crisis.

links.text: -"Virus cases leap in Nigeria's Kano". Radio France Internationale. Agence France-Presse. 1 May 2020. Retrieved 2 May 2020.-

Data.event_text: 6 May  Olalekan Hameed is sentenced to death in a trial broadcast on Zoom for the murder of his employer's mother.

links.text: -"Coronavirus: Nigeria's death penalty by Zoom 'inhumane'". BBC News. 6 May 2020. Retrieved 7 May 2020.-

Data.event_text: 15 May  A controversial plan to close Koranic schools in 19 northern states and sending ′′almajirai′′ (″pupils″) home results in spreading COVID-19. Sixty-five boys test positive in Kaduna, 91 in Jigawa, eight in Gombe, and seven in Bauchi State.

links.text: -"Coronavirus in Nigeria: The child beggars at the heart of the outbreak". BBC News. 16 May 2020. Retrieved 17 May 2020.-

Data.event_text: 18 May  Boko Haram extremists attacked a village just as people were preparing to break their Ramadan fast after sundown, killing at least 20 people in the first attack of its kind in northeastern Nigeria since the holy month began.

links.text: -Umar, Haruna (18 May 2020). "Authorities: Boko Haram attacks Nigerian village, killing 20". Associated Press. Retrieved 18 May 2020.-

Data.event_text: 30 May  #JusticeForUwa is trending in Nigeria, with the family of Uwavera Omozuwa family appealing for help to track down her rapists and killers in a church in Benin City, Edo State.

links.text: -"#JusticeForUwa trends in Nigeria after student murdered in church". BBC News. 31 May 2020. Retrieved 1 June 2020.-

Data.event_text: 9 June  Gunmen suspected of belonging to Boko Haram kill 81 villagers in Borno State. Another 20 people are killed in an attack in Katsina State.
10 June  The World Trade Organization accepts the nomination of two-time Nigerian minister Okonjo-Iweala as its Director-General.

links.text: -Udo, Bassey (10 June 2020). "Nigeria: WTO Names Okonjo-Iweala Among Candidates for DG Election". allAfrica.com. Retrieved 13 June 2020.-

Data.event_text: 11 June  An Aide-de-camp to First Lady Aisha Buhari is arrested after shooting at presidential nephew and aide Sabiu Yusuf when the latter refuses to go into self-isolation after a trip to Lagos.

links.text: -"Nigeria: Gunshots in Presidency As Aisha Buhari Moves Against President's Aide, ADC Arrested". allAfrica.com. 13 June 2020. Retrieved 13 June 2020.-

Data.event_text: Comments by Senator Bola Tinubu, National Leader of the All Progressives Congress
All 36 of Nigeria's governors resolved to declare a state of emergency over rape and other gender-based violence against women and children in the country.

links.text: -"Nigeria: All 36 Governors Declare State of Emergency Over Rapes and Violence". allAfrica.com. Voice of America. 13 June 2020. Retrieved 13 June 2020.-

Data.event_text: U.S.-based streaming company Netflix pairs up with filmmaker Mo Abudu, owner of EbonyLife TV (ELTV), to create two new TV series and several films.

links.text: -Aisha Salaudeen (12 June 2020). "Netflix partners with Nigerian filmmaker in new major deal". CNN. Retrieved 27 June 2020.-

Data.event_text: 22 June  Cross River gorillas including babies, once thought to be an extinct species, are captured on film by conservationists in the Mbe Mountains near the border with Cameroon.

links.text: -Petesch, Carley (8 July 2020). "Rare gorillas in Nigeria captured on camera with babies". Associated Press. Retrieved 8 July 2020.-

Data.event_text: 8 July  Nnamdi Azikiwe International Airport in Abuja and Murtala Muhammed International Airport in Lagos reestablish domestic flights after a three-month shutdown; other airports will open soon. No date has been given for the resumption of international flights.

links.text: -Achirga, Abraham (8 July 2020). "Nigeria restarts domestic flights amid easing coronavirus restrictions". Reuters. Retrieved 8 July 2020.-

Data.event_text: 13 July  A retired American woman was rescued by a Police Intelligence Response Team after being held hostage for 15 months by a 34-year-old man in a hotel. The man had extorted US$48,000 from her.

links.text: -"American woman freed after being held captive in Nigeria". Associated Press. 13 July 2020. Retrieved 13 July 2020.-

Data.event_text: 18 July  Between three and 16 security forces died and up to 28 are wounded in an attack inside a forest near Jibia in Katsina state.

links.text: -"World News - BBC News". BBC News. Archived from the original on 31 July 2022. Retrieved 19 July 2020.-
-"World News - BBC News". BBC News. Archived from the original on 31 July 2022. Retrieved 19 July 2020.-

Data.event_text: 23 July  Militants from the Islamic State West Africa Province, which broke away from Boko Haram several years ago, claimed responsibility for killing five aid workers who were kidnapped last month in northeastern Nigeria.

links.text: -"Islamic State group says it killed 5 aid workers in Nigeria". AP NEWS. 23 July 2020. Retrieved 25 July 2020.-

Data.event_text: 29 July - Fourteen people are killed in a mass shooting in Kogi State.

11 August  Musician Yahaya Sharif-Aminu, 22, is sentenced to death by hanging in Kano State for blasphemy against Muhammad. A number of Independent UN human rights experts, including the UN Special Rapporteur in the field of cultural rights, Karima Bennoune, urged the Government to immediately release the singer.

links.text: -"Nigerian singer sentenced to death for blasphemy in Kano state". BBC News. 10 August 2020. Retrieved 17 September 2020.-
-"Rights experts denounce death sentence against Nigerian singer who posted on WhatsApp". UN News. 28 September 2020. Retrieved 13 February 2021.-

Data.event_text: 20 August  The army regains control of Kukawa, Borno, where the Islamic State West Africa Province (ISWAP) had taken hundreds of captives on 18 August.

links.text: -"Nigerian army says 'in full control' of town where hostages taken". www.aljazeera.com. Retrieved 20 August 2020.-

Data.event_text: 23 August  Two die in clashes between security forces and Biafran separatists.

links.text: -"Nigerian security clash with Biafra separatists turns deadly - DSS". Reuters. 23 August 2020. Retrieved 24 August 2020.-

Data.event_text: 25 August - Eighteen people were killed after Islamic State in West Africa militants planted an improvised explosive device on the road between Monguno and Baga, Borno.

links.text: -"Nigerian soldiers and police killed in IS ambush in Borno state". BBC News. 27 September 2020. The Nigerian military says 18 people have been left dead after an ambush on a government convoy in the north-east of the country. It said four soldiers, 10 police officers and four civilians were killed in the attack targeting Borno state officials on Friday.-

Data.event_text: 20 October - Lekki massacre in the #Endsars protest, armed security personnel use live bullets to disperse crowd in Lekki leading to casualties and fatalities. Lagos State's governor declares a 24 hours curfew in the state.

links.text: -"End Sars protests: People 'shot dead' in Lagos, Nigeria". 21 October 2020.-

Data.event_text: 30 October  NaijaHacks, Africa's largest Hackathon, holds NaijaHacks from home 2020 Hackathon.

links.text: -MENAFN. "NaijaHacks announces the 2020 virtual NaijaHacks from home". Retrieved 21 September 2020.-

Data.event_text: 31 October - United States Navy SEALs from the Naval Special Warfare Development Group rescued a 27-year-old American hostage held captive by armed gunmen near the border with Niger.

links.text: -Schmitt, Eric (31 October 2020). "Navy Commandos Rescue American Kidnapped in Niger". The New York Times.-

Data.event_text: 14 November  Witnesses say that soldiers shot civilians during a peaceful protest is Lagos on 20 October.

links.text: -George, Libby (14 November 2020). "'The soldiers kept shooting:' witnesses testify in Lagos protest probe". Reuters. Retrieved 15 November 2020.-

Data.event_text: 29 October − Mawlid Muslim and public holiday
14 November  Witnesses say that soldiers shot civilians during a peaceful protest is Lagos on 20 October.

links.text: -George, Libby (14 November 2020). "'The soldiers kept shooting:' witnesses testify in Lagos protest probe". Reuters. Retrieved 15 November 2020.-

Data.event_text: 28 November - Koshebe massacre 110 civilians and peasant farmers were killed and six were wounded as they worked in rice fields in Koshebe village. It is the deadliest attack against civilians in Nigeria this year.
8 December  Amnesty International says 10,000 civilians have died while in police custody since the beginning of the Boko Haram insurgency in 2011.

links.text: -Olukoya, Sam (8 December 2020). "10,000 Nigerians died in military custody, alleges Amnesty". Associated Press. Retrieved 8 December 2020.-

Data.event_text: 14 December  About half the 800 boys kidnapped by bandits in Katsina State are still unaccounted for.

links.text: -"Nigeria school attack: Gunmen who seized children in Katsina 'surrounded'". BBC News. 14 December 2020. Retrieved 14 December 2020.-

Data.event_text: 16 December  Seventeen of the schoolboys kidnapped by Boko Haram are rescued and two are killed; 300 are still unaccounted for.

links.text: -"17 Nigerian students rescued from Boko Haram, two dead: Official". aljazeera.com. Al Jazeera English. 16 December 2020. Retrieved 17 December 2020.-

Data.event_text: 18 December  The schoolboys are released. One hundred girls kidnapped in the 2014 Chibok kidnapping are still missing.

links.text: -"Nigerian official: More than 300 abducted schoolboys freed". AP NEWS. AP. 17 December 2020. Retrieved 18 December 2020.-

Data.event_text: 22 December  Eighty Muslim schoolboys are kidnapped and then released in Katsina State.

links.text: -"More students abducted in Nigeria but are quickly rescued". AP NEWS. 20 December 2020. Retrieved 22 December 2020.-

Data.event_text: 25 December  Boku Haram militants kill eleven people and burn a church in Pemi, Borno State.

links.text: -"Boko Haram kill villagers in Christmas Eve attack". BBC News. 25 December 2020. Retrieved 26 December 2020.-

Data.event_text: 29 December  The International Monetary Fund estimates the GDP of Nigeria at US$442.976 billion, making it the largest in Africa and the 26th largest in the world.

links.text: -Emejo, James (29 December 2020). "Nigeria Remains Largest Economy in Africa, 26th in the World - IMF". allAfrica.com. This Day. Retrieved 3 January 2021.-

Data.event_text: 31 December  Traditional Christian "crossover" end-of-year celebrations are subdued as churches are held to 50% capacity. Nigeria has had 85,500 confirmed cases of the coronavirus and 1,260, although the actual totals may be higher because of a low testing rate.

links.text: -"Nigerian worshippers at a loss as 'crossover' prayers cancelled". The Guardian. Agence France-Presse. 31 December 2020. Retrieved 31 December 2020.-

Data.event_text: December  Akwa Ibom Christmas Village is inaugurated by Governor Udom Emmanuel.

links.text: -Udonquak, Aniefiok (31 December 2020). "Akwa Ibom Christmas village generates over N1 billion in one month -". Businessday NG. Retrieved 15 January 2024.-

Data.event_text: 22 December  Sambisa Memorial Day, Borno State
25 December  Christmas Day (Christian holiday)
26 December  Boxing Day public holiday
